values:
It'll have scrollwork sort of like this, only in green frosting.  Four tiers, scalloped like this one:

Only the tiers will be seperated by columns--which will also have the scrollwork on them--and decorated with yellow roses.

And now we have cake--or at least we will.  Cake that's about half the cost that most bakeries charge.  Yay!  It'll be white with green sroll-y decorations and yellow roses.  We're thinking pink champagne with raspberry filling, chocolate with coconut pecan filling, and orange almond with bavarian cream filling.  Nummers!

Forgot to mention--we also have a minister.

Also, I have shoes. With peekaboo toes!  Here's a picture:

Cute, no?  And the heel is only 2", so it won't make me too tall (or too sinky?).  Here's hoping the grass isn't too soft!  I will be bringing backup white flipflops!

We picked out tuxes this weekend.  Men's Wearhouse is cool and uses flash on their site, though, so I can't post pictures. But they are Jones New York (Because the lady said they're more athletically cut), one button (because the choice was one or three), notch collar.  The vests are all kind of diamond studded--it's hard to describe, but basically it was just about the only pattern that came in yellow rather than pukey gold, and the matching green pattern is about the same shade as the girls' dresses, so we went with it.  And the dads will have silver.  Even though the girl tried to talk us into gold.  Whateva!  The white one looked funny, though, because the diamonds were silver, so Dan got a different texture with connected diamonds.  Because he can be different and special.  Oh, and neckties.  And the shirts that have the collars that go better with neckties instead of bowties, whatever those are called.  Pointed?  Anyway.

We have the photographer for sure.  She's also going to do an engagement photo session with us for an extra $50.  It will be a good way to see what it's like to work with her, and to see how the pictures come out.

Last but not least...we bought a ring for Daniel.  So we're doing pretty good as far as the important, must-have stuff goes.  Cake is next!
Dresses are ordered!  Here's a picture. We got this shade of green, with white ribbon and trim instead of pink. Brittney's dress is yellow with white.

Invitations are ordered!  We even found ones that were inexpensive enough that we could splurge on some colored ink.  Big spenders, I know.  We cut cost by deciding to print our own reception/RSVP info...I'll probably find some stationary somewhere and make an insert to go in the invitations.  Oh, and when we were ordering them we realized that we needed to set a time, which we hadn't done yet.  So we went with 4:00--hopefully early enough to be done with the ceremony and pictures before people start to get hungry, but late enough to give us time to set up, and to take advantage of the cooler, shadier part of the day for the reception (also it's technically afternoon so tea-length dresses for the 'maids will still be socially acceptable. That way they'll be cooler, and can change into flip flops later without worrying about hemlines).

Hopefully bridesmaids dresses will be chosen and ordered this weekend, too.  And maybe we'll even book a caterer.  What progress!

Oh, also I'm looking at paper and bamboo parasols...they're $25/dozen from the oriental trading co.  We can leave them plain white or paint them.  I thought the ladies in the party might enjoy some shade during the ceremony.  I think if guests used them they would block each others' view, but maybe we can have some on hand for people to use during the reciption.  ...just a thought.  Paper fans are another thought, they're $3-5 a dozen.

P.S.  I have my dress on hand; it's sort of a load off.  Well, not on hand...I stached it in my parents' attic.  Still...it's here, all safe and sound and waiting for me to find a low-in-the-back, strapless bra and kitten-heel shoes so I can get it altered (it needs to be taken in pretty much all over...)

We bought 12 big paper lanterns from Target...green, yellow, and white.  They were only $60 for the lot, and they run on batteries so we don't have to worry about stringing cords.  We think the colored ones should go in the tent(s) and the white ones in the trees outside.  Progress!

I ordered a dress today! They had one my size in the factory, so it will be here in 3 days instead of 12 weeks! I'm posting pictures behind the cut.  

I'm not going to post the pictures of me trying it on, but...

In theory, the dress will come with spaghetti straps.  And if not, I will put some on.  I just think it looks better that way.  It has decorations all the way down, but they're pretty spaced out and not too glittery or opulent, so I think it's ok.  I'm going for something that is relatively simple, but still looks like a wedding dress rather than a prom dress...

Brittney was very emphatic that she likes buttons.  Well, I like them, too.

Here's detail.  Flowers all the way!  The ladies in the stores were always shoving tiaras on my head.  I'm not going to wear a tiara; I much prefer flowers.
Hopefully Dan is cool with the asymmetry.  There were some asymmetrical dresses that he said he liked, and others that he said looked lopsided.  I know the strapless/spaghetti wasn't really the sleeve/neckline of choice either, but...oh, well.  This way he will be completely surprised, since it looks nothing like the dresses we looked at together.

Ok., here are the dresses the 'maids are looking at. They all like them, but they're a little spendy so we're investigating cheaper alternatives. Too bad UGLY is "in" for prom this year. 


This is the green color...



And this would be Miss Brittney's dress, since she is special and gets to wear something different.  And looks great in yellow.

Here's a couple pictures of the place we booked for the reception.  It's called O & L Nofziger Gardens.  Basically it's the home of LaVerne Nofziger, who has a large piece of property, a penchant for gardening, and an entrepreneurial nature.  There are white lights strung around the oak grove, and swings hung from some of the trees. There's not a certain time we have to leave, candles and lanterns are ok, tents are ok, firepits are ok (thought it might be good in case it gets chilly), fireworks are ok as long as they're not close to the field that borders the site (which will probably be drying out by then). The place comes with 200 chairs and 12 round tables and table linens, which is one of the main reasons why we chose it instead of a cheaper site that doesn't have that stuff (chairs rent for about $1.50 apiece, and tables $7.  I have no idea how much linens cost). It has an outdoor kitchen (tent) with 3 fridges, water, electricity, and a stove. There is an adjacent field where everyone can park. It has a dance floor of sorts (basically just a covered platform, nothing too special to look at but maybe we can dress it up). And it has horseshoes, hawt dawg!

Anyway...the site is pretty. There are gardens up front, but the grove will mostly be what we make it....it's basically just a large space in a pretty setting.  I am thinking that different types of old fashioned lanterns would be cool to use as centerpieces, since the reception will be in the evening.

Anyway. Pictures.

Yay, swings!


There are planter boxes on that antique....farm thingie.  There will be flowers.

The gazebo by the stream.  This picture, and the one that follows, are more in the "gardens" area than the reception area.  We can use the gardens, but the tents and tables will be in the grove.  And there will be flowers growing...right now there's just a few daffodils.

Another gazebo, overlooking the fields.

Finally!  I browsed around on the internet forever.  I couldn't narrow down all the dresses that caught my eye, so Dan helped.

I like the shoulders and the back of the skirt.

I like this one...in this shot the diamond shape on the abdomen looks a little weird, I would probably have to see it in person.  Here's detail:

Here's the back:

I rather like the back.

I am a fan of the back of this one, although the front kind of looks like a nightgown.

I like this one.  Not the one on the right!  I like the shoulders and the V-shaped corset.  It looks a lot like the one at the top, no?  It's the same designer, but this one's 2006 and the other one is 2005.  Way to change things up!  I can only assume that the backs are different.

I am a fan of the shoulders on this one.  Sure, the train would get in the way if I want to dance, but...*shrugs*  It's pretty, who cares if it's functional!

I got all excited about this one because it has a detachable train.  Brilliant!  I like the cap shoulders, the V-shaped corset, and the relatively slender and simple skirt.  Here's detail:

Here's the back:

It's pretty.  Here it is without the train:

Yay!  I can dance in that one!

I kind of like the simplicity of this one.  Good for a garden reception.

This one's asymmetrical, but not in-your-face about it.  I like the lines.

There!  Comments and criticism are welcome.  I'm going shopping on Saturday, starting at about 10,  if anyone wants to come!

So here's what we're thinking so far for colors....the bridesmaids' dresses a light green, like this, perhaps?

...these look kinda bluish right now, but I swear they were green earlier.  We could also go for a shade like these ladies have...

Or this one, which again is starting to look less green next to the others....


Honestly, any shade is ok for the dresses as long as it's greenish and it looks good on a human.  We are thinking yellow for flowers.  Or various shades/types of yellow flowers, or flowers that have yellow in them (like daisies and lilies).  As Daniel pointed out, having various shades of the two colors will make it look less U of O-ish.

So...yeah, that's what we're thinking so far.

Here are some places that we plan to go look at as possible wedding or reception sites. Additional suggestions are welcome.

The Oregon Garden 
http://www.oregongarden.org/NE_weddings.html
$2,000 - $3,500 (ack!)

Silver Creek Falls 
http://www.oregonstateparks.org/park_211.php

Belknap Hot Springs
http://www.belknaphotsprings.com/
$250 and up depending on which facilities we get

Hanson Country Inn, Corvallis
http://www.hcinn.com/

Greengable Gardens, Philomath
http://www.greengable.com/

Eugene Yacht Club
http://www.eugeneyachtclub.org/about/visitor.html

Corvallis Methodist Church
http://www.corvallisfumc.org/fumchome.htm

Avery Park Corvallis
http://www.ci.corvallis.or.us/index.php?option=content&task=view&id=564&Itemid=505

Willamette Park Corvallis (I think this is the right one)
http://www.ci.corvallis.or.us/index.php?option=content&task=view&id=591&Itemid=532
